summary: This is a formal letter from the French Ministry of Justice to the U.S. Department of Justice, transmitted via the U.S. Embassy in Paris. It explains French law regarding extradition, specifically stating that France will not extradite its own nationals, and that this nationality is assessed at the time of the alleged offense.

persons.name: Andrew Finkelman
persons.context: Serves as the Liaison Magistrate at the U.S. Embassy in Paris, acting as the conduit for this official communication from the French Ministry of Justice to the U.S. Department of Justice.

persons.name: Philippe Jaegle
persons.role: Head of the Office for the International Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters
persons.context: The French official who authored and signed this letter on behalf of the Directorate of Criminal Affairs and Pardons, outlining the legal impediment to extradition.

events.title: French Ministry Issues Extradition Clarification
events.description: The French Directorate of Criminal Affairs and Pardons sends an official letter to the U.S. DOJ, via the U.S. Embassy liaison, clarifying that French law prohibits the extradition of French nationals, with nationality assessed at the time of the offense.

keyFacts: French law (Article 696-4 of the Code of Criminal Procedure) prohibits the extradition of French nationals.
The nationality bar to extradition is assessed based on the individual's nationality at the time the alleged offense was committed.
Losing French nationality after committing an offense does not remove this legal impediment to extradition.
The letter is a formal response to a U.S. request, indicating the U.S. was seeking the extradition of a person of interest from France.
The document implies the person sought for extradition was, at the time of the alleged offense(s), a French national.
